title: Which molecule has the most lone pairs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, if we restrict our answer to diatomics (in which scenario we can discount long chain polyethers) would it not be a dihalogen? And in the difluorine molecule, [math]F_{2}[/math], there are SIX such lone pairs, four in dioxygen, and two in dinitrogen…and with respect to [math]F_{2}[/math], because these are smaller, and more localized on an atom of HIGH nuclear charge, the [math]F-F[/math] bond length is UNUSUALLY longer than it should be on the basis of repulsive interaction between lone pair orbitals on the ADJACENT atom of the same molecule…
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Mohammed Saiful Alam Siddiquee

response.answer_text: Assuming you can make a polymer of arbitrary length, there is no upper bound. … -CH2-CH2-O-CH2-CH2-O-CH2-CH2-O-CH2-CH2-O- … [The above is a representation of poly(ethylene glycol). Each oxygen atom, of course, has two lone pairs.]
